reviewText: Great little platformer that pays hommage to the NES era. Does away with everything fancy and focuses on getting the gameplay right. No weapons outside of your fists (true ninja!), no crazy combos and most certainly no dubstep. Would think the chosen colour pallete might be hard on the eyes or make the game more difficult but it did not. Keyboard was manageable but gamepad is recommended, both were able to be remapped. Supports 4k+ screen resolutions, unlimited fps and 120hz+ panels.\nhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B0z3rmcFbVA\nPrice is low due to the length not the quality, 7 worlds to traverse each with a boss fight at the end. Levels contained collectable coins that are used to unlock 'extras', which generally made the game more difficult, eg no checkpoints. Veterans will find it on the easyside but still very enjoyable and worth a playthrough for the price.

reviewText:
Mute Crimson+ does a good job bringing that feeling old games used to give us.
A Gameplay & Review video showcasing the features I'm going to talk about:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4WUVPSkTqTA
You can double jump, slash your sword and climb walls. Similarly to the old Ninja Gaiden games.

The controls are responsive, which is very good for a game like this. You won't ever feel like the game cheated your death.
The music is really catchy, and helps get you into the mood of the game.

Although the art style is similar to older games, the animation itself is way better. It's nice and smooth. It looks really cool.

The game has 8 chapters. As you progress through the game, it gets harder. There are also collectibles scattered around if you want the extra challenge. If you die before getting to a checkpoint, you'll need to grab the collectible again. You're rewarded with some extra rewards if you collect enough of them, such as: Classic Mute Crimson mode, and disable checkpoints.

At the end of each chapter, you're also met with a boss. They're a nice change of pace. Before and after a boss, you're treated to some cutscenes. The dialogue consists of broken English. I'm pretty sure it's done like that on purpose, to emulate the times some older games were badly translated from their Japanese versions.

Fun game, with some really cool music.

Recommended!

reviewText:
TL;DR --> GODDAMMIT NINJA STOP GRABBING THAT WALL

------------------------------------------------------------------------

Ah, another gem hidden in the indiegame ocean, waiting for being discovered by all of you.

Mute Crimson+ (Plus) is exactly what you see in the store page: another successful attempt into recovering the old gaming spirit with a very complete 2D platformer, difficulty-growing levels and a set of different worlds or zones. This game is actually a huge update of an older Mute Crimson game, which is actually included as well if you want to try it.

The main character doesn't have many different resources and skills but I can tell the dev made some effort to squeeze them, and to feel that every level feels very different. Mastering this game might require some practise since the jump mechanics feels quite odd at first. But once you get the hang of it the experience turns to a much more pleasant session.

Every world features some different levels with a unique background condition (i.e World 2 levels will have wind and you'll have to deal with it the best you can) plus a boss fight at the end, which is your common pattern-learning thing.

PROS:

+ Charming pixel style contrasting black/white with red (being anything red as hostile).
+ This game features Engrish!!! It's totally intended and adds a very original fact that most people have forgotten.
+ Catchy chiptune/8-bit music that gets on well with the rest of the game very properly.
+ A total of 7 worlds and 7 bosses, with about 50 levels in total. I would say that a blind run might take you from 3 to 4 hours.
+ Growing difficulty that ends to be pretty challenging. If you're an experienced platformer player then you'll only find issues from world 5 to beyond, but if you're more of a newcomer get ready for one hell of a run!
+ Many different game modes, including Boss Rush (<3) and Arcade Mode speedrunning (9 lifes for the whole game).
+ Challenging achievements not meant for everybody!

NEUTRAL:

· Getting the collectibles is needed in order to unlock further modes. I'm usually against this but since they add some sort of extra challenge into levels it wasn't that bad.

CONS:

- No diagonal detection for gamepad players. I know oldschool games didn't have it either (joysticks came much later in the end) but that's the kind of thing I would pass since it's a little adapt to the nowadays devices. Several times I died because some frames before grabbing a wall I was pressing my joystick more up" than "left/right"
date:
causing me not to grab it and therefore die.

OVERALL:

Mute Crimson+ is a very enjoyable platforming experience
recommended: getting us back to the old days in the best of ways. I can see a lot of feeling put into its developing and despite not being crafted for eveybody
hoursPlayed: I'm sure all of you will appreciate how good and polished this game is.\n\n8.25/10"
voteText: January 15

reviewText:
This game was reviewed with a key from the developer

Gameplay Footage and Video Review: http://youtu.be/yhykYpjtvSE

Summary:
It's a remaster of sorts from an old Xbox Live title, and for a 5 dollar indie title, you get a reasonable experience. The strongest element is the game's aesthetic, as the red, white, and grays aesthetic and animation quality definitely makes for an experience that's visually appealing as the blood scatters on the walls. The difficulty curve is a good progression over time, even if the game doesn't necessarily have that strong of a variety. The controls are strong as it give you enough precision to get you through some of the more tricky elements of the game, while not being too forgiving. The length will be an issue for some, but for 5 bucks, can you really ask for that much out of it? A solid 5 dollars title.

Lists:

+:
Strong aesthetic with good use of minimal colors.
Great animation quality.
Strong appropriate controls.
The bad “translated” dialogue seems to be purposeful, and is hilarious.
-:
Some boss fights are pretty boring.
Length isn't that long, even on the more difficult sections.
Some inconsistent rules can lead to a death or two. Once you realize, it doesn't happen again (don't touch blood)

reviewText:
I highly recommend this game! To me it felt like I was playing a Classic Mega Man while using Zero from the X series, all the while with a Super Meat Boy vibe to it.  There are very intense platforming moments, memorable bosses as well.  It definitely is a challenge as it is a OHKO game, but everything feels rewarding and like an awesome challenge more than it is frustrating. I had very, VERY few moments where I felt frustrated.

Every world has a gimmick that is used throughout the levels so the entire game feels fresh as you play through it and figure out how to handle each one.

Bosses were a tad difficult at times, but again, I found it more to be a fun challenge than a burden of defeating it.

The music is fantastic, every track is wonderful to listen to throughout each world.

The color scheme is minimal, which I like. Everything is in black and white other than hazards, enemies, bosses, and some background elements.  You also can change the color in the options menu to a variety of colors to suit how you want to play.

Easily one of my new favorite games on Steam. This is a must play!

The gameplay is tough but fair. There are no cheats" in the level design

reviewText:
I first played Mute Crimson on Xbox Live Indie Games.  The graphics and gameplay have great improvements, but the game was great even in that first version.  This is an excellet platformer in the style of NES era games such as Ninja Gaiden while adding some more modern gameplay design elements.

I have stayed in contact with the developer after talking with them in the XBLIG days (so I cannot claim I'm not biased).  I do not however play these kinds of platformers regularly - just not my thing.  Mute Crimson has been an exception however, and I've also been fasinated with the quality of level design present in the game.

If you are more interested in my thoughts on the level design, check out the video below.  As for my review - I think it's a great game in both mechanics and charm that will appeal to more than just the hard core platformer fan.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uxjtw1Fe944

reviewText:
Mute Crimson + - A Steam Review
[Disclamer - I was provided a copy of by the publisher for review purposes]

The good
Clean pixel graphics
Funny cutscenes
Great controls and overall gameplay
The not so good:
Some blind jumps that are a bit unfair to the player
The conclusion:
If you like Super Meat Boy, stop reading and go buy this game. If you don’t, maybe being an awesome ninja will convince you to try this. It’s an awesome platformer and the gameplay changes enough to keep you playing over and over.
And the cinematics are so, so quotable. 9/10, would platform again!
You can see me playing it here - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lylkexRgc0I

reviewText: Wow.  For a ninja themed platforming game with simply controls and straightforward levels, this is one serious little game!  The levels are well laid out and the idea is simple, anything red all over will definitely kill you.  There are coins that you can collect, at your peril I dare say, that unlock certain game cheats or bonuses that only serve to make the game harder to be quite honest like, no continues for example.  The music and sound effects are top notch in this game as well and lend a hand in creating the familiar NES feel of eight bit gaming.  As I said earlier, the controls are super easy to use.  Only two buttons are used in game with the d-pad/control stick and that too gives the game an NES feel since the NES only had two buttons on their gamepads anyway.  All of this familiarity doesn't just stick out in the graphics/art/sound and controls either.  The levels are no nonsense and straight to the point kind of like Ninja Gaiden or Castlevania.  The bosses at the end of each level are also pretty well designed and definitely have been programmed like bosses from the great old days of NES too!  The challenges of the game are pretty damn good and will have veterans of the platforming genre memorizing their layout and timing.  All in all a great game and well worth the price of admission!  Get this game if you like platforming a la Mega Man, Ninja Gaiden and others of the platforming genre!  A must have for the low, low price!

reviewText:
You control a ninja that has to save the world!!! very intuitive, with a nice flow and very fun game.

You have to jump, double jump, climb, evade traps, compensate to the actions of the environment and... as you are a ninja - Slash all the enemies to get to the final boss of each level.

As you progress you pass through checkpoints where you re-spawn if you die - so you can theoretically end the game in 1 go, but as you can see in my fight against the first boss it can take a while -;P

The game is spot on on the retro felling from the menus to the music to the colors and movements.

I enjoyed it and recommend it - it also drops Steam cards

reviewText:
This is an enhanced remastering/remake of Mute Crimson (not plus) that was on the indie marketplace on the X360.

The core of the gameplay is still there.  You're a ninja that can double jump, jump slash, and climb on walls.  As the ninja you travel various areas to defeat the army of monsters invading the planet.  You can only take one hit so some repetition of certain sections of the level will be had.  Even more so when obtaining collectibles that will allow you to unlock some neat stuff.

Also, if you are colorblind(to red or more), or you want a different color than red, the game provides a colorblind mode so you can change the color.

Overall I've completed the plus and classic modes of this game and, even though I've done almost all of it, the game is fun and is replayable.

Gameplay: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wlVVM_l7VLg

reviewText:
Just another retro platformer?

Yeah, kinda. But if you like oldschool NES platformers like me, it's not a bad thing at all. Mute Crimson has everything we used to love and hate in the old days and executes it all well. My only complaint is that your character tends to stick to the walls when you don't want to and Engrish in cutscenes (which is a nice touch otherwise) felt bit forced at times.

Otherwise, a solid game that shouldn't be overlooked.

reviewText:
Mute Crimson+ is an awesome retro platformer that can be ruthless at times when it comes to the difficulty though because of this, I really enjoyed the game.

The controls are extremely fluid and responsive which is needed especially for the tight jumps where one wrong move can lead to instant death from traps, falls and enemies. I also love that the checkpoints are very common throughout the game, so if you die at a certain stage you never have to replay a huge chunk of the game. The soundtrack also suits the game perfectly!

Great job with Mute Crimson+ Iced Lizard Games, I recommend this game for people who are after a solid platforming experience while also keeping in touch with their retro side! :)

reviewText: Incredibly addictive. Challenging. The epitome of what platformers should be. Each level design is unique, and while you can treat the first 1/3 - 1/2 of the game like you would most modern platformers (i.e. it takes skill, but to an extent you can succeed just on luck and repeated attempts), ultimately end level gameplay is reminescient of a time when the only way to win was to learn to intuitively feel" the pattern/ timing when making jumps to dodge death. If you can't sense that you need to jump while you still see the laser glowing red in front of you in order to make it to the next section where it's safe to stand
voteText: until you stop f@!#ing around and pay attention to the timing.The developers did a particularly great job of forcing you to re-calibrate /learn new timing patterns after each section (of which there are 3-4) in of each of the levels
votesHelpful: and avoided that platformer burnout you get when you feel like you're making the same jumps all the time. There are mid-level save points
votesTotal: and the spacing is perfect. Far enough apart to make it difficult
votesFunny: close enough to not make you rage quit. Definitely worth the money (or even twice as much as they're charging)."

reviewText:
Overall it's a great game with absolutely hilarious writing. However, the difficulty curve is a bit confusing at times. Sometimes you'll find a pretty long and challenging section without a single checkpoint (see video below for one example) and other times you'll have more checkpoints than you'd know what to do with. I guess it's one way of increasing difficulty, but I would be hard pressed to say that it's a good way to do so. An overly long section where you're chased by lava while running through a gauntlet of timing based precision platforming challenges that you have to restart if you die (and you will die if you e.g. miss a cycle) is just not fun to me. I mean, I like challenging precision platformers more than most people (probably) but this particular section just isn't fun to me. Not in the slightest.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0KdpCMNs0oQ

But as I said, the rest of the game is great, hence the thumbs up. Absolutely worth the money in spite of its flaws.

reviewText:
Great aesthetic. Faithful retro look with detailed backrounds and smoothly animated sprites. The red + grayscale color scheme worked perfectly.

Music fit the look and theme. Very old school in a good way.

Difficulty was, in my opinion, perfect. It took me about 4 hours to complete. Difficulty ramped up pretty steadily, starting extremely easy and finishing quite difficult.

Gripes:
-some of the perils had slightly too big of hitboxes, especially the flying skulls. It seemed they were a pixel or two too big. Some of the grass looking stuff also had the same issue.
-no way of knowing that when you reached a boss, it hard saved, given that checkpoints generally didn't hard save.

For anyone who likes old school platformers this is an absolute no-brainer. I'd even recommend it to people who like platformers in general. It's charming, fun, and doesn't overstay its welcome. The price is great too.
